key_points: Florida police arrested a student, John Hagins, for planning a school shooting after students reported his Snapchat messages.
Hagins, 19, faces charges of terrorism, written threats to injure or kill, and attempted first-degree homicide.
The arrest was made by the Daytona Beach Police Department, and Hagins is held without bond at Volusia County Jail.
Two students reported Hagins' concerning Snapchat messages to authorities, potentially thwarting a mass shooting.
Daytona Beach Police Chief Jakari Young emphasized the importance of reporting such threats to prevent violence.
Hagins referenced the 1999 Columbine High School shooting in his messages.
He sold his car to buy a folding rifle and ammunition, and posted about being 'finished with his school shopping' on Snapchat.
Hagins planned to go to a shooting range for practice and targeted the last day of the semester for maximum impact.
Police found a backpack with ammunition and the rifle in Hagins' apartment on campus upon arrest.
The president of Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University praised the students and police for their swift action.
